Bettercare • Bettercare books • Ebola Prevention and Control • Test

Test 2: Patient management

Please choose the one, most correct answer to each question or statement.

  1. What is an Ebola outbreak?
    1. A common rash seen with Ebola
    2. A severe form of bloody diarrhoea in an Ebola patient
    3. One or more patients with Ebola in a country
    4. At least 10 patients with Ebola in a single hospital
  2. What is a case definition for Ebola?
    1. The hospital record number of a patient with Ebola
    2. A set of criteria used to assess whether the patient has Ebola or not
    3. The post mortem result of a patient who has died of Ebola
    4. A case summary of a patient who has died of Ebola
  3. What is an epidemiological risk factor for Ebola?
    1. A person younger than 15 years of age
    2. Someone living in any African country
    3. Anyone with a fever
    4. Contact with an Ebola patient or corpse in the last 21 days
  4. Which symptom is common in Ebola?
    1. Chest pain and shortness of breath
    2. Severe headache and muscle pains
    3. Blurred or double vision
    4. Painful, stiff joints
  5. Which clinical sign is common in patients with Ebola?
    1. Fever
    2. Jaundice c. Enlarged lymph nodes d. Oedema of the legs
  6. How soon can a person become ill after contact with a patient with Ebola?
    1. Within 24 hours
    2. As early as 4 days
    3. Usually after 21 days
    4. Sometimes as late as 28 days
  7. Bleeding and bruising:
    1. Is uncommon in Ebola
    2. Occurs in all Ebola patients
    3. Is an early sign of Ebola
    4. Usually starts after 7 days in patients with Ebola
  8. Once the Ebola virus enters the body it rapidly multiplies:
    1. In the cells of lungs
    2. In the cells of the bone marrow
    3. Only in the cells of the immune system
    4. In many different types of cell
  9. Ebola is most infectious:
    1. In the week before the patient becomes ill
    2. As soon as the patient becomes ill
    3. Just before they die
    4. When they start to recover
  10. What is an important complication of Ebola?
    1. Hypertension and stroke
    2. Bowel perforation and peritonitis
    3. Heart failure and pulmonary oedema
    4. Dehydration and shock
  11. What organ often fails in patient very ill with Ebola?
    1. The heart
    2. The kidneys
    3. The lungs
    4. The spleen
  12. What is the death rate in the current Ebola outbreak?
    1. 10%
    2. 50%
    3. 70%
    4. 100%
  13. How should suspected Ebola patients be transported?
    1. They should not be moved but nursed at home
    2. They can be safely moved on public transport
    3. A routine ambulance can be used provided the staff wash their hands well
    4. Personal protective equipment must be worn by the ambulance staff
  14. What is an important part of supportive care in a patient with Ebola?
    1. Keeping them nil per mouth to avoid vomiting
    2. Giving them a diuretic to treat heart failure
    3. Fluid replacement
    4. Giving morphine for pain
  15. Are pregnant women at increased risk of dying from Ebola?
    1. Yes
    2. Only if they go into labour and deliver
    3. Pregnancy gives them some protection against Ebola
    4. No
  16. Should patients with Ebola be actively resuscitated if they collapse in an under-resourced hospital?
    1. Yes as this is an important part of good patient care
    2. Only if they look as if they may survive
    3. Only if they have been given an anti-Ebola drug first
    4. No as the risk of infection of the staff is extremely high
  17. When can a patient with Ebola be discharged home?
    1. When the bleeding stops
    2. When they are no longer shocked
    3. When they are feeling better
    4. When they have had no fever for at least 3 days and are clinically better
  18. What disinfectant should be used to clean patientsâ€™ clothes?
    1. 70% alcohol
    2. A lime solution
    3. A 0.5% chlorine solution
    4. Soap and water 19 How should corpses be prepared for disposal?
    5. They should be placed in 2 leak-proof plastic bags, each of which must be carefully disinfected
    6. They must be burned immediately
    7. They should be soaked in a lime solution for 24 hours
    8. It does not matter as corpses are not infectious
  19. What role can the family play in burying a patient who has died of Ebola?
    1. There is no need for any precautions
    2. They can touch the body if they wash their hands well afterwards
    3. They can wash the body with soap and water
    4. They can prepare the coffin and help dig the grave
